subject: Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: Just want to put things back into context ... As you see I never said that /tests/ /drive/ your design. I said that /TDD/ /guides/ my design. TDD != tests and
messageBody:
Just want to put things back into context

> That's reasonable, Joe, and also how I do it, but I was commenting on this
> quote:
>
> I think, when doing TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it is to guide
> your design.
>
> ... which strikes me as questionable.
>

As you see I never said that /tests/ /drive/ your design. I said that
/TDD/ /guides/ my design. TDD != tests and guide != drive.

> I would also point out that the term "Test-Driven Design" strongly seems to
> imply that your tests drive your design. Which is what I was objecting
> against.

Did I write test driven design? I dont think so. But then again I do
think that TDD is more about design than testing so maybe it /is/ a
good term. I'll have to think about that.

>, and also why I much prefer calling it "Test-Driven Development"
> (and I still think that it's something you should do whenever you can but
> you certainly don't need to do it 100% of the time to obtain well-tested
> code).

Whenever I can is certainly most if not all of the time. Sometimes I
don't know how to do it and then I do something else or try harder
until I do. I guess sometimes it is slower and sometimes it is faster,
I'm just not a very good judge of when it is faster or not and I get
surprised sometimes that things that seem easy are not and the other
way around. But the goal is not only to have well tested code is it?
